original_fears: Social anxiety in large lecture halls
original_challenges: Making friends in a new environment

current_challenges: Mind going blank when trying to start conversations

evolution_stages.conversation_summary: Problems discussed: 1) Freezing up in social/academic interactions, 2) Fear of judgment when asking questions, 3) Avoidance of networking/office hours. Solutions offered/accepted: 1) Scripting low-pressure conversation starters, 2) Reframing 'dumb question' anxiety, 3) Role-playing scenarios (e.g., library seat request). Student's response: Initially hesitant but agreed to practice and acknowledged small past successes. Evidence of progress: Willingness to role-play, self-awareness about rehearsal habits, and plan to initiate one interaction this week.

triggers_specified.Campus social events: Overwhelm in crowded settings with unfamiliar people
triggers_specified.Office hours: Anxiety about asking 'dumb questions' or taking up the professor's time

evolution_stages.conversation_summary: Problems discussed: 1) Social freezing during networking/office hours, 2) Fear of judgment when asking questions, 3) Physical anxiety symptoms. Solutions offered/accepted: 1) Scripted low-pressure openers, 2) Role-played scenarios with tweaks for voice/body language, 3) Planned rejection responses. Student's response: Initially hesitant but engaged in 3 practice rounds with observable improvement in speech pace and posture. Evidence of progress: Willingness to attempt real-world library interaction tomorrow using practiced techniques, plus insight that 'shaking is normal'.

evolution_stages.conversation_summary: 1) Problems discussed: Social anxiety in initiating conversations, fear of judgment in academic settings, and avoidance behaviors. 2) Solutions offered/accepted: Role-playing specific scenarios (library seat request), cognitive reframing techniques, physical anchoring methods, and the 5-second action rule. 3) Student's response: Initially hesitant but engaged in multiple practice rounds, demonstrated willingness to try strategies in real-life (planned library attempt), and identified a personal reward system. 4) Evidence of progress: Successfully modified speech patterns during practice, developed contingency plans for rejection scenarios, and verbalized commitment to implementation with specific time/place details.

evolution_stages.conversation_summary: Problems discussed: 1) Social freezing during interactions, 2) Fear of judgment in academic settings, 3) Avoidance of social opportunities. Solutions offered/accepted: 1) Scripted conversation starters, 2) Physical anchoring techniques, 3) 5-second action rule, 4) Normalization of awkward moments. Student's response: Initially hesitant but engaged in multiple role-play rounds, demonstrated measurable improvement in delivery, and committed to real-world attempt. Evidence of progress: Transitioned from 'I always sit alone' to creating concrete implementation plan with self-reward system, showing both cognitive and behavioral shifts.
